thread.title: Boys Soccer: Lakeland gets past West Milford, 2-1
thread.title_full: Boys Soccer: Lakeland gets past West Milford, 2-1

title: Boys Soccer: Lakeland gets past West Milford, 2-1
text:
Buy this photo Photos by Ron Nowak Lakeland's Alden Powers competes for a loose ball with West Milford's Nick DeAngelis (17) and Eric Gangi in the Lancers 2-1 win on Tuesday.West Milford's Ian Barrett scored his team's only goal in Lakeland's 2-1 victory last week. Defending on this play are Daniel Ingram (4) and Greg Huebner. 
WEST MILFORD - The Lakeland and West Milford boys' soccer teams have had similar seasons, losing more games than they won and, at times, having problems scoring goals. 
On Tuesday, against West Milford, Lakeland was the more opportunistic team on offense and played solid on defense. That combination translated into a 2-1 victory. Buy this photo 
"Our defense didn't bend, didn't break," said winning coach Don Peterfriend, who noted that three of his back-liners are underclassmen. 
The Lancer defense turned away all but one of the Highlanders' attacks, refusing to allow West Milford's attackers to split the seams in Lakeland's back line. 
On offense, the Lancers scored their two goals within about 12 minutes spanning the first and second halves, taking a commanding 2-0 lead. 
Lancer Matt Pierce recorded a goal and assisted on James Holm's score that came with about seven minutes left in the first half. Holm found himself unmarked during a Lancer counterattack. 
Pierce netted what proved to be the clincher about two and a half minutes into the second half, again on a Highlander defensive lapse. 
Lakeland goalie Josh Schaffer was solid in net, stopping several of West Milford's quality scoring chances in the opening half of play. 
The Highlanders' response to Lakeland's goals came about five minutes into the second half when forward Ian Barrett headed a beautiful pass from Eric Gangi past Shaffer. 
Lakeland's defense, however, was able to withstand a furious Highlander onslaught in the final 30-minutes. 
"They controlled the flow of the game from the back," said Peterfriend of his defense. 
"Two (goals) for us is a lot," he commented, noting that his team is starting to play well as the state tournament looms on the horizon. "Hopefully we'll get to the state tournament and see what happens."
